docs.lead_paragraph: It began with a slight headache across my temples, the sort of feeling you would expect after a long day of meetings. By the time I returned home, I had begun to feel flu-ish. The headache became a migraine, concentrated behind my eyes, as though a pair of imps were squatting under my frontal lobe, kicking at my sockets. I spent the night vomiting, delirious, with a fever that crept close to 104 degrees. That was only the beginning of a monthlong ordeal. I had contracted dengue (pronounced deng-AY), a mosquito-borne virus for which there is no specific treatment and no vaccine, despite the fact that it afflicts an estimated 50 million people every year. And I had caught it right here in prosperous, squeaky-clean Singapore. Unlike the mosquito that carries malaria, a parasitic disease of the world's tropical backwaters, dengue's courier is a striped urbanite called Aedes aegypti.

headline.main: A Mosquito's Gift in Singapore: A Bad Case of Breakbone Fever

docs.abstract: Wayne Arnold Cases article describes his personal experience when he contracted dengue fever in Singapore; discusses history of illness, its symptoms and efforts to combat spread of disease; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Coping with dengue, a mosquito-borne virus for which there is no specific treatment and no vaccine.

docs.lead_paragraph: The start of school can also mean the start of head lice season, and the unpleasant choice of picking lice out or poisoning them. Now there is a new approach: a lotion that suffocates the bugs. According to a study released yesterday in the journal Pediatrics, the lotion rid 95 percent of a group of 133 children of their head lice. The study was conducted by the inventor of the lotion, Dr. Dale L. Pearlman of Family Medical Center in Menlo Park, Calif.

headline.main: A New Approach to Fighting Lice

docs.abstract: Dr Dale L Pearlman of Family Medical Center in Menlo Park, Calif, leads study on new lice-killing lotion that he invented; lotion suffocates bugs; research is published in journal Pediatrics (S)
docs.snippet: There is a new approach to fighting head lice in schools: a lotion that suffocates the bugs.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM -- A nightcap will help you sleep. THE FACTS -- A century ago, it was common for Americans to don soft, fuzzy caps before crawling into bed. The comfy hats locked in warmth and aided sleep. Nowadays, nightcaps tend to come in the form of a glass of whiskey or two, and many people will tell you that alcohol is a good antidote to the occasional bout of insomnia. But while a drink before bed might help you drift off to sleep, in the long run, experts say, it would most likely cause tossing and turning throughout the night.
docs.abstract: Research suggests that alcohol before bed can disrupt sleep; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: While a drink before bed might help you drift off, in the long run it would most likely cause tossing and turning throughout the night.

docs.lead_paragraph: A new kind of prescription can be filled online, but it does not involve using the Internet to order drugs. Physicians call it an information prescription, and a study released yesterday found it to be effective in guiding parents toward reliable Web sites. The article, published in The Archives of Pediatric and Adolescent Medicine, said a large body of research had found that well-informed patients tended to do better.
docs.abstract: Dr Donna M D'Alessandro of University of Iowa leads research into use of internet prescriptions to help direct patients to valid medical information; study involved 197 patients at univeristy pediatric clinic; average prescription contained 10 sites; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: A new kind of prescription can be filled online, but it does not involve using the Internet to order drugs.

docs.lead_paragraph: Reading may be a uniquely human talent, but it is not an innate skill. Writing systems differ vastly from one culture to the next. Chinese, for example, is composed of thousands of logographic symbols, while English has a mere 26 alphabetical building blocks. A new study suggests that the biology underlying reading disorders may also vary by culture. Chinese speakers who suffer from dyslexia, the study found, have different brain abnormalities than English speakers who are dyslexic. The report was published last week in the journal Nature.

headline.main: Biology of Dyslexia Varies With Culture, Study Finds

docs.abstract: Dr Li-Hai Tan of National Institute of Mental Health authors study that finds that dyslexic individuals who read and speak Chinese have different brain abnormalities than those afflicted with dyslexia who read and speak English; research, published in journal Nature examines differences in alphabet-based languages and ones that use complex symbols and suggests that could be root cause for learning differences; 15 percent of Americans and 7 percent of people in China are dyslexic (M)
docs.snippet: A new study suggests that the biology underlying reading disorders may also vary by culture.

docs.lead_paragraph: In the midst of tragedy, with her husband dying, 30-year-old Leisha Nebel-Taylor made a surprising phone call. She asked a urologist, would it be possible to retrieve and store some of her husband's sperm after his death? In this case, the doctor, Peter N. Schlegel of the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, said yes. But more often than not, he turns down such requests, he said.

headline.main: In a Wife's Request at Her Husband's Deathbed, Ethics Are an Issue

docs.abstract: Bioethical issue of removing sperm from man who has died discussed; Leisha Nebel-Taylor holds that she had right to dying husband's sperm and doctors should not have power to deny her wish; Dr Cappy M Rothman, California Cryo Bank urologist and medical director who performed only postmortem sperm retrieval to result in successful birth, holds all requests for sperm retrieval should be considered (S)
docs.snippet: In the midst of tragedy, a wife asks if it is possible to retrieve and store some of her husband's sperm after his death.

docs.lead_paragraph: Cardiac rehabilitation programs make a huge difference in the health of patients who have suffered a first heart attack, a Mayo Clinic study has found, but only about half of such patients make use of them. Women and patients over 65 took part in the programs in even lower numbers, the study said.
docs.abstract: Dr Veronique L Roger leads Mayo Clinic study on effectiveness of cardiac rehabilitation programs in improving health of patients who have suffered first heart attack; research, published in Journal of the American College of Cardiology, shows substantially higher death rate for patients who do not participate in programs; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Cardiac rehabilitation programs make a huge difference in the health of patients who have suffered a first heart attack, but only about half of such patients make use of them.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: JOURNAL OF THE AMERICAN COLLEGE OF CARDIOLOGY

docs.lead_paragraph: Exercise helps diabetics improve their ability to metabolize sugar. But for those patients who don't feel up to the Stairmaster, a new study offers some comfort: the exercise involved in walking downhill, the researchers found, leads to even bigger improvements than hiking up. The study was presented last week at a conference of the European Society of Cardiology and was led by Dr. H. Drexel, a cardiologist at the Academic Hospital in Feldkirch, Austria.
docs.abstract: Dr H Drexel, Academic Hospital (Feldkirch, Austria) cardiologist, leads study on impact of exercise on ability of diabetics to metabolize sugar; research, presented at European Society of Cardiology conference, shows that patients metabolize more sugar when they hike downhill than they do hiking uphill; suggests eccentric exercise, like hiking downhill, may increase blood flow; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: The exercise involved in walking downhill, researchers have found, leads to even bigger improvements for diabetics than hiking up.

docs.lead_paragraph: Through the tropics of mid-August, Michael Maccari, a men's clothing executive, was at it 10 to 12 hours a day, fretting over the details of an imminent holiday shipment to stores, the fittings for the spring 2005 lines and the designs for next fall -- three seasons, three sets of deadlines. But right now, at lunch hour on a Wednesday, the deadlines were dissolving beneath a gentle tide of deep breathing.

headline.main: Working Long Hours? Take a Massage Break, Courtesy of Your Boss

docs.abstract: Second of three New York Times articles: The Yoga Cure, Sick Of Work, describes work-instituted relaxation programs designed to help employees deal with workplace stress; Dr Lawrence Murphy, National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health psychologist who has reviewed workplace studies, holds that effects of relaxation programs are short-lived; Dr Peter L Schnall of University of California, Irvine, Center for Occupational and Environmental Health suggests that reducing job stress by empowering workers with more control over their job is best way to reduce stress and potentially increase productivity; various company-sponsored programs described; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Companies across the country are offering yoga and meditation classes to help employees relax, reduce stress and recharge.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH

docs.lead_paragraph: If you waited until your children started school to take them to the dentist, you waited too long. Good dental care starts in infancy, even before the first tooth emerges. By school age, children should be well on their way to a lifetime of healthy teeth and gums. Few of us are naturally inclined to have a healthy mouth. Good oral health depends on proactive measures: frequent daily cleaning; the control of destructive habits like lip biting and thumb sucking; consumption of adequate fluoride; application of topical fluoride and a dental sealant; a wholesome diet with a minimal consumption of sweets and refined starches, especially between meals; and periodic care by a dentist knowledgeable about the special oral needs of children.

headline.main: Dental Advice: Start Early. Very Early.

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses importance of good dental care for infants and young children; suggests that parents become actively involved in child's development of good eating and brushing habits; describes child's first dental visit and what to expect; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Good dental care starts in infancy, even before the first tooth emerges.
